content: I didn't know Alphabay, it was a bitcointalker from the local French forum who mentioned it. Given the fate of Ross Ulbricht (imprisoned then recently released against all odds) and Alexandre Cazes (dead at 26), whose businesses lasted around 2 and a half years each before the final downfall, I wondered why they didn't stop sooner, when they were already very rich. What motivates these people, who have become criminals, to continue their business when in the end they live in extreme danger? Initially, they were not particularly disadvantaged (which sometimes could explain the choice of a criminal path) and, unless I'm mistaken, they are quite intelligent and could have embarked on a successful career. Here are a few hypotheses : 1. Ideology and Libertarian Vision (for Silk Road)Ross Ulbricht (Silk Road) was not just a criminal looking for money (I just saw a documentary and some witnesses, including his girlfriend at the time, say that one of his objectives was clearly to make as much money as possible). He saw his site as a libertarian revolution, a way to bypass government control and enable free and anonymous trade.He believed in crypto-anarchism, where Bitcoin would eliminate banks and regulations.He kept going despite the risks, thinking of himself as a pioneer of a world without government surveillance.2. Addiction to Power and ControlAt a certain point, it was no longer just about money but power. Running a darknet empire provided an immense psychological thrill and a sense of being untouchable.Criminals like Ulbricht and Cazes must have tought they were too smart to get caught.3. The Illusion of InvincibilityAs their sites grew, they believed they had perfected their anonymity and security. Ross Ulbricht thought that his use of Tor and Bitcoin made him impossible to track.Alexandre Cazes was living a luxurious life in Thailand, convinced that law enforcement would never catch him.4. Greed and the Difficulty of StoppingEven though Ulbricht was motivated by ideology, he was earning millions of dollars in commissions. Cazes, on the other hand, was clearly money-driven, owning luxury cars, villas, and millions in crypto.When running an illegal platform generating millions per month, it’s hard to say, “I’ll just stop and walk away.”5. Business Pressure and User DependenceOnce their sites were running, shutting down meant losing all control and risking leaks of information. Darknet vendors and buyers depended on them and expected reliable service.A site like AlphaBay or Silk Road couldn’t be sold like a traditional business, so the only way out… was often getting arrested.It would seem that money isn't everything, and that even the richest criminals keep on doing what they're doing until they're caught or killed.They seem to love power and adrenalin; for some, fear is part of everyday life and not a problem.I think it's a risky life that's hard for parents to accept (when you're not a criminal yourself).

comments.author: Botnake
comments.body: People who have experienced both wealth and power can never afford to lose them anymore. So even if they accumulated a lot of wealth already, living in such luxurious life, their greed towards bigger wealth in the future is still there. So why not stop when they have all the chances and opportunities to keep it going? With money, power can be bought, which means if they got more money, the more powerful they will be. I think that’s how greedy a man is, they won’t stop chasing for more wealth and power, until someone will put an end to it.

comments.body: That's the question that I have but to be honest, I think that they are not normal people, they are different, that's why they risk that much in life and start what they start, i.e. crime business.I think that when they start this business and achieve success, stay alive for a year, two years and so on, they start to think that they are immortal. comments.author: PrivacyG
comments.body: I believe it was rather a combination of your hypotheses.  It can be any combination of any of the points from 1 to 5 and they may have come across some of the points in time, not right from the beginning.There is definitely a sense of being 'invincible'.  A sense I some times get while browsing Tor and taking all possible precaution to leave as little fingerprints as possible, but then I remind myself who I would be playing against if they ever wanted to look for me.  Laws and regulations are your friend until a three letter agency decides to not play by the rules any more and to do you dirty.  After they do, does it matter to anybody whether they found you in a rather dirty way or not?  You are caught.  Your life is ruined.  Everybody knows what you have done, there is no point of return now.The addiction to power and control are things that may be generated in time or at least enhanced by the users too.  If I launch a Cryptocurrency and people spam my Personal Messages praising me for my Cryptocurrency and calling me a God, I may develop a sense of superiority and start believing I am actually better.It is easy to say 'stop' when you have not accomplished that level of 'success' yet.  When you are up there and the stakes are high, when you know where you came from this becomes really tough on your mind.  You made millions.  You made a thousand steps to get there but are only ten steps away from your next couple of millions.  What do you do, do you stop?  Or do you continue?

comments.body: Because most people are greedy fucks.  I know for a fact that if I had uber wealth, the majority of it would go to animal welfare as well as to helping those less fortunate.  These people who start to amass hundreds of millions of dollars can't help themselves, it's like a disease.  My favorite example right now is Jerry Reinsdof (spelling?) the owner of my once beloved chicago bulls and my never beloved white sox.  Old man could keel over any day now, and all he's concerned about is making money.  The Bulls fucking suck, yet have had the NBA's highest attendance for two past years.  That's all he cares about, so he doesn't spend money on players, why would he? Ross seems to have got caught up in that trap.  Though I think he's probably a decent guy, I just don't know what true and what's not with his story.

comments.author: EFS
comments.body: Even if they had pulled the plug early, they would've been caught due to the clues they left behind. The main goal here wasn't to get rich but to do something revolutionary. Silk Road had achieved this. Even though it was mostly used for bad purposes, it was still a rebellion against authority. It was a big move for the free market. Governments see things like this as a direct challenge to their authority.Laws don't have universal truths. What's legal in one place can be illegal somewhere else. All they did was allow free trade. Just because it's banned in your jurisdiction doesn't mean it's banned everywhere. But they learned the hard way that there's no such thing as unlimited freedom in this world.
